snippet.textDisplay: My second question has to do with how the progression of the game affects the story (I.e: the updates that add more stuff). Are we to assume all the new things were just there to begin with in a logical progression or are the updates the equivalent of a new discovery in the Minecraft world when the update in real life happens? If it is the former, then a previous theory, which is not lore heavy but still was a theory nonetheless, has a few kinks as Mattpat talks about there only being a specific set of items available at the time. On the other hand, if it is the latter, then the theory of the Illagers being the ones to have made the zombies, creepers, skeletons, and other mobs would be in direct contradiction to it as 1: these mobs were all in the game before Illagers and their mansions, and 2: the Illagers being outcasted would actually be an extremely recent event in Minecraft terms. This answer will also effect the follow ups to my first question because again if the Illagers were just recently expelled, they must have VERY QUICKLY picked up building but again the Villagers had been there far longer and still haven’t picked it up.
snippet.textOriginal: My second question has to do with how the progression of the game affects the story (I.e: the updates that add more stuff). Are we to assume all the new things were just there to begin with in a logical progression or are the updates the equivalent of a new discovery in the Minecraft world when the update in real life happens? If it is the former, then a previous theory, which is not lore heavy but still was a theory nonetheless, has a few kinks as Mattpat talks about there only being a specific set of items available at the time. On the other hand, if it is the latter, then the theory of the Illagers being the ones to have made the zombies, creepers, skeletons, and other mobs would be in direct contradiction to it as 1: these mobs were all in the game before Illagers and their mansions, and 2: the Illagers being outcasted would actually be an extremely recent event in Minecraft terms. This answer will also effect the follow ups to my first question because again if the Illagers were just recently expelled, they must have VERY QUICKLY picked up building but again the Villagers had been there far longer and still haven’t picked it up.

snippet.textDisplay: Wait Mattpat, in an earlier video you reference the fact that the villagers cannot build, but their exiled enemies can? Are we just assuming they picked it up to survive or are we changing that old statement which throws some counter-evidence in that previous video (referring to the enderman one). I apologize if someone has already answered this question; this just bothers me because it is almost certain that the illagers made these mansions as they are so specific to the wants and needs of the illagers and not anyone else (unless we assume this cult started before the fall of the ancient civilization which seems to be contradicted by other theories). If these structures were truly made by the Illagers, then why were they the only ones to learn how to build because I doubt they were out casted just for that and it would be weird if only the villagers that could build to be outcasted. Even if they picked it up after being outcasted to survive, you would think that the villagers would do the same as they are constantly raided and slaughtered by zombies and Illagers. This also leads to a follow up question I will put in a separate comment.
snippet.textOriginal: Wait Mattpat, in an earlier video you reference the fact that the villagers cannot build, but their exiled enemies can? I apologize if someone has already answered this question; this just bothers me because it is almost certain that the illagers made these mansions as they are so specific to the wants and needs of the illagers and not anyone else (unless we assume this cult started before the fall of the ancient civilization which seems to be contradicted by other theories). If these structures were truly made by the Illagers, then why were they the only ones to learn how to build because I doubt they were out casted just for that and it would be weird if only the villagers that could build to be outcasted. Even if they picked it up after being outcasted to survive, you would think that the villagers would do the same as they are constantly raided and slaughtered by zombies and Illagers. This also leads to a follow up question I will put in a separate comment.

snippet.textDisplay:
I had this thought at 3am but....Ghasts:

First off they drop ghast tears, and whenever they make noises it sounds like an altered version of someone screaming/crying. Also they always have their eyes closed, but open them when they see a player (something no other mob in the game does) and not only do they just open their eyes, but they also make an almost surprised face.

I don’t know about you but the theorist alarm sure seems to be going off over here.
snippet.textOriginal:

Hey I've got a thoery, if those illagers and the others if they were able to make a zombie then did they find a head from a past builder and make herobrine? That might be dumb but look at the video they used a pumpkin to make a zombie so, They will be able to make another steve which will explain the wool in some of the rooms so, My theory is herobrine didnt come as a glitch in the files/codes in the game, He might have came into minecraft by the illagers we've got the proof.


Proof: There was some past builders in the world of minecraft so it will make sense to have an evil past builder to get his/her head off by the nice builders so if they found the head they would try to build another builder that'll make and do anything that the illagers want but when they tried to make the builder something went wrong it didn't do anything that the illagers said that is how herobrine was made now he is looking at our every move and seeing what we do to learn our strength or atleast our strategy to survive he has seen us fight the enderdragon and the other mobs even his creators now he is going to see if we can survive him.
And that was my mini theory that the illagers made herobrine.

snippet.textDisplay: Alright, random thought, but I was wondering how the Illagers knew to try to make replicas of Steve supposedly before they existed in the world, as TONS of zombies exist once you get in. This whole outcast situation happened way before you spawned (I'm assuming when you spawn in is when you come into existence kind of, as you start with nothing). Well, what if Steve was the Illager's one success in creating a sort of immortal being? His incredible strength and ability to respawn come to mind. But after being created, he fled the illagers with nothing, immediately making him a target (Which is why the Illagers now attack him).

snippet.textDisplay: I have a theory how to fix the lore when the piglins will come out... --> What if new Minecraft updates move us more and more back in time to the older moments of the lore... --> For example piglins degraded due to time and turned into zombie pigmen. My proof is that when villages where first introduced they were empty! I think it's because all the villagers in that point of time went extinct...  In the older versions of Minecraft we had less naturally generated structures, because these versions of minecraft represent much older minecraft world than we know... That's maybe why in the older versions we only see pyramids and stuff like that...
snippet.textOriginal: I have a theory how to fix the lore when the piglins will come out... --> What if new Minecraft updates move us more and more back in time to the older moments of the lore... --> For example piglins degraded due to time and turned into zombie pigmen. My proof is that when villages where first introduced they were empty! I think it's because all the villagers in that point of time went extinct...  In the older versions of Minecraft we had less naturally generated structures, because these versions of minecraft represent much older minecraft world than we know... snippet.textDisplay: MatPat, I would also like to call attention to Minecraft's weather. The wind literally only blows in one direction, as you can see from the clouds. And rain can also happen spontaneously without any storm clouds gathering. Something is quite clearly wrong with this world's magnetic field in order to push every wind in the same direction. The winds are also never enough to do more than slowly push the clouds, at a constant rate, mind you, and gently ruffle banners, and things like that. It is never enough to create tornadoes, hurricanes, sandstorms, or even blow out torches. This also brings up another issue: If the winds are always gentle, even when it's raining, then how does lightning occur? Especially since they're always blowing in the same direction! Lightning should, by all rights, be impossible. Yet another problem is how completely different biomes, ones with different climates, temperatures, soil content, etc., can exist right next to each other. I have no clue what this means for Minecraft, but I wanted to point you towards these strange and possibly fatal facts.
snippet.textOriginal: MatPat, I would also like to call attention to Minecraft's weather. The wind literally only blows in one direction, as you can see from the clouds. And rain can also happen spontaneously without any storm clouds gathering. Something is quite clearly wrong with this world's magnetic field in order to push every wind in the same direction. The winds are also never enough to do more than slowly push the clouds, at a constant rate, mind you, and gently ruffle banners, and things like that. It is never enough to create tornadoes, hurricanes, sandstorms, or even blow out torches. This also brings up another issue: If the winds are always gentle, even when it's raining, then how does lightning occur? Especially since they're always blowing in the same direction! Lightning should, by all rights, be impossible. Yet another problem is how completely different biomes, ones with different climates, temperatures, soil content, etc., can exist *right* *next* *to* *each* *other.* I have no clue what this means for Minecraft, but I wanted to point you towards these strange and possibly fatal facts.

snippet.textDisplay: So I'm gonna just make a random base theory for Blazes and someone needs to work on the end of it. The old builders evidently made the Blazes as blaze powder is used in eyes of ender. The question is why and how. Well we can assume they were made for protection of the nether fortresses but from what? every mob in the nether is fire resistant so what are they guarding against. And how well I reckon they are made out of netherite. As we can find scraps everywhere making me believe the old builders used it. Netherite is proven to be magnetic thanks to the lodestone block which can make a compass point to it and Blazes can fly which I believe is due to magnetic fields. I just can't figure out how the old builders gave them come form of pyromancy. So that's where I leave it up to everyone else. Thanks for your time

snippet.textDisplay:
Wow I just realized. Isn't weird how you, the last survivor of an a dead race of people randomly just appear out of nowhere when you join the game. What if the illagers got it right and somehow created you and you appeared in some random place on the overworld. They somehow, after centuries have revived a species long extinct with you.


Maybe.. to go even further, the illagers actually added a little something extra to creating you, something that will make their creation better than the member of their previous species. They added something that will make sure that their creation cannot be killed, they gave you the ability to respawn after you die that way you can't ever truly die.
Idk just a theory I came up with like five minutes ago that I had to put in the comments. I hope Matt sees it.
snippet.textOriginal:

What if the illagers got it right and somehow created you and you appeared in some random place on the overworld.  They somehow, after centuries have revived a species long extinct with you.  


Maybe.. to go even further,  the illagers actually added a little something extra to creating you, something that will make their creation better than the member of their previous species.  They added something that will make sure that their creation cannot be killed, they gave you the ability to respawn after you die that way you can't ever truly die.  
Idk just a theory I came up with like five minutes ago that I had to put in the comments.  I hope Matt sees it.

You should totally do a theory on ARK: Survival Evolved. A game that appears to be an open world survival game that has hidden lore in the little chests you find. Kinda reminds me of something... I just can’t remember it.

snippet.textDisplay: What if Illagers are the good guys? I've been working on this theory for a while, and I'm wondering what people think about it. First off, minecraft is evolving. I dont mean the gameplay or updates, I mean the people. They went from just having small villages that were practically useless to highly specialized villages, and humans (because illagers are still human) who are learning to use more complex technology and magic. And one thing that I think is overlooked in this game a lot is lightning. Minecraft lightning is certainly nothing like lightning in the real world, in fact, it seems to have almost magical qualities in many cases, being able to transform several mobs. Keep that in mind, it's important later. Eventually, these technologically and magically advanced humans began to quarrel with the ones more focused on tradition, and tensions built up. Then one day, the end realm was discovered, a place ruled by the ender dragon, who had the power to destroy all of them if it wished. A group of humans banded together to try and find a way to fight this powerful being, by creating the ultimate human. Steve. (Hear me out). They experimented with creating life, their prototypes resulting in snow golems and iron golems. Everything was progressing well when they made a mistake. It seemed like true life wasnt something easily tampered with, and their Steve experiments created the zombie, the most dreaded foe of the villagers. The villagers who valued tradition saw this as a reason to exile the advanced villagers, who became known as illagers. However, they did not give up. They knew that they couldn't harness the power to create this ultimate human, so they focused on something else instead. A beast with the strength of an iron golem and the utility of a horse. The ravager. Unfortunately, they still needed life for that, so they raised nearby villages to kidnap villagers and iron golems, and fuse them together into the closest thing they could create to a boss monster. The ravager experiments were successful, and they abandoned the steve experiments, leaving the materials where they stood. Maybe they finally stood a chance.Eventually, they were ready. Armed with magic, technology, and their ravages, they launched their attack, only to be utterly destroyed. The ender dragon created the wither. The wither tore the surface world to bits, clouding the sky with ash and twisting all life into hellish creatures. The wither, as you may remember, seems to have a lightning like shell around itself. The power of this lightning converted the world as we know it into a charred warped version of itself, which over the centuries became the nether. The illagers that made it to the endwere trapped there and eventuallybecame endermen, slaving away to construct ender cities for all eternity. Gradually the power of the lightning left very few creatures left, but the humans were fortunate enough to evolve. The ones with powerful enough magic to survive the blast became piglins. Piglins are very humanoid, with inventories, bartering, structures, and the fact that they only fight when attacked. The piglins tried to recover the remains of their civilization before the wither, butdidnt find much. Until centuries in the future, when the earth surrounding the Steve experiment withered away. The powerful lightning from the wither had been just what was needed to give Steve life, and he had been trapped there for a long time, unconscious. The piglins saw their opportunity to change fate, so they taught him everything they knew, including training him on using his inventory. Finally, when the time was right, they sent him back in time te try and change the way events turned out.
snippet.textOriginal: What if Illagers are the good guys? I've been working on this theory for a while, and I'm wondering what people think about it. First off, minecraft is evolving. I dont mean the gameplay or updates, I mean the people. They went from just having small villages that were practically useless to highly specialized villages, and humans (because illagers are still human) who are learning to use more complex technology and magic. And one thing that I think is overlooked in this game a lot is lightning. Minecraft lightning is certainly nothing like lightning in the real world, in fact, it seems to have almost magical qualities in many cases, being able to transform several mobs. Keep that in mind, it's important later. Eventually, these technologically and magically advanced humans began to quarrel with the ones more focused on tradition, and tensions built up. Then one day, the end realm was discovered, a place ruled by the ender dragon, who had the power to destroy all of them if it wished. A group of humans banded together to try and find a way to fight this powerful being, by creating the ultimate human. Steve. (Hear me out). They experimented with creating life, their prototypes resulting in snow golems and iron golems. Everything was progressing well when they made a mistake. It seemed like true life wasnt something easily tampered with, and their Steve experiments created the zombie, the most dreaded foe of the villagers. The villagers who valued tradition saw this as a reason to exile the advanced villagers, who became known as illagers. However, they did not give up. They knew that they couldn't harness the power to create this ultimate human, so they focused on something else instead. A beast with the strength of an iron golem and the utility of a horse. The ravager. Unfortunately, they still needed life for that, so they raised nearby villages to kidnap villagers and iron golems, and fuse them together into the closest thing they could create to a boss monster. The ravager experiments were successful, and they abandoned the steve experiments, leaving the materials where they stood. Maybe they finally stood a chance.Eventually, they were ready. Armed with magic, technology, and their ravages, they launched their attack, only to be utterly destroyed. The ender dragon created the wither. The wither tore the surface world to bits, clouding the sky with ash and twisting all life into hellish creatures. The wither, as you may remember, seems to have a lightning like shell around itself. The power of this lightning converted the world as we know it into a charred warped version of itself, which over the centuries became the nether. The illagers that made it to the endwere trapped there and eventuallybecame endermen, slaving away to construct ender cities for all eternity. Gradually the power of the lightning left very few creatures left, but the humans were fortunate enough to evolve. The ones with powerful enough magic to survive the blast became piglins. Piglins are very humanoid, with inventories, bartering, structures, and the fact that they only fight when attacked. The piglins tried to recover the remains of their civilization before the wither, butdidnt find much. Until centuries in the future, when the earth surrounding the Steve experiment withered away. The powerful lightning from the wither had been just what was needed to give Steve life, and he had been trapped there for a long time, unconscious. The piglins saw their opportunity to change fate, so they taught him everything they knew, including training him on using his inventory. Finally, when the time was right, they sent him back in time te try and change the way events turned out.
